titleText: Analysis Finds Geographic Overlap In Opioid Use And Trump Support In 2016
teaserText: Counties with higher rates of opioid use skewed heavily Republican in the 2016 election. What role did the opioid epidemic play in President Trump's victory?

titleText: Sarah Sanders Joins List Of Top Trump Aides Confronted At Restaurants
Zimbabwe's President Emmerson Mnangagwa Unharmed After Explosion At Campaign Rally
3 Charts That Show What's Actually Happening Along The Southern Border
Grenade Attack Tears Through Rally For Ethiopian Prime Minister
teaserText: Shortly after Abiy Ahmed addressed a massive rally in the capital, Addis Ababa, a blast sent attendees running. Authorities say at least one person died in the attack and its aftermath.

titleText: U.S. And South Korea Agree To Suspend Upcoming Military Exercises Indefinitely
teaserText: The announcement of additional suspensions follows the summit between President Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un earlier this month.

titleText: Katie Arrington, S.C. Republican Who Beat Mark Sanford, Is Badly Injured In Car Crash
teaserText: The state lawmaker surprised the political world when she upset the incumbent in a GOP primary just a week and a half ago. Now, Arrington is in the hospital after a fatal collision Friday night.

titleText: Playing Hanafuda With The Hand You're Dealt
teaserText: As a fourth-generation Japanese American, photographer Will Matsuda tries to unpack some of the liminal spaces of cultural identity in America. He grew up playing hanafuda, a Japanese card game.

titleText: A Global Guide For Leery Travelers
teaserText: Is your destination too dangerous? How do you protect yourself from health threats?

titleText: Large Methane Leaks Threaten Perception Of 'Clean' Natural Gas
teaserText: A new study finds that oil and gas operations are leaking 60 percent more methane than previously reported by the federal government.

titleText: Children's Cries Brought Down Walls Of Indifference
teaserText: Thousands of migrant children have been separated from their parents by the U.S. government. NPR's Scott Simon reflects on audio recordings this week in which detained children can be heard crying.

titleText: Gaming Addiction Disorder; White House Pitches Big Changes For Education Department
teaserText: Also in our weekly roundup of education news, the Federal Commission on School Safety met publicly to brainstorm ideas around how to make schools safer.

titleText: Officials Say Illegal Pesticide Caused Deaths Of 13 Bald Eagles In Maryland
teaserText: Authorities said there is an "epidemic on the Eastern Shore" of wildlife-poisoning crimes because it's "cheaper and easier" than trapping a nuisance animals or building a fence.

titleText: In Major Privacy Win, Supreme Court Rules Police Need Warrant To Track Your Cellphone
teaserText: The justices ruled 5-4 that the Fourth Amendment does not allow police to obtain moment-by-moment tracking of an individual's cellphone location.

titleText: FACT CHECK: Trump, Illegal Immigration And Crime
teaserText: In an effort to justify his get-tough policies at the southern border, President Trump met Friday with victims of crimes committed by immigrants who entered the country illegally.

titleText: What To Know About Turkey's Elections
teaserText: On Sunday, voters will elect a president and parliament in snap elections called by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who has amassed broad powers over the years. Here's a look at what's at stake.

titleText: More Oil From OPEC May Not Mean Relief At The Gas Pumps Anytime Soon
teaserText: Drivers might be cheering OPEC's decision to increase oil production, but analysts say the extra supply isn't expected to drive gasoline prices down in time for summer vacation season.

titleText: Crying Toddler On Widely Shared 'Time' Cover Was Not Separated From Mother
teaserText: The image has been tied to a border policy separating migrant families. But in this case, daughter and mother were detained together — and the White House says it's proof the controversy is overblown.

titleText: Fearing Deportation, Some Immigrants Opt Out Of Health Benefits For Their Kids
teaserText: A growing number of American children are losing out on Medicaid — and other programs — because their parents are undocumented immigrants and fear detainment and deportation.

titleText: Protests Erupt In Spain As Men Held In 'Wolf Pack' Sex Assault Get Bail
teaserText: Judges freed five men convicted of sexual abuse of an 18-year-old woman during Running of the Bulls festivities as they appeal the verdict. The move sparked a call for an overhaul of sex crimes laws.

titleText: Your Favorite Summer Jams
teaserText: From the sultry Calvin Harris and Dua Lipa song "One Kiss" to Korean boy band BTS's "Fake Love, NPR listeners share the songs they'll have on repeat this summer.

titleText: John Coltrane's Lost Album A 'Buried Treasure' For Jazz Fans
teaserText: Never-before-heard John Coltrane recordings from a 1963 session are being released as a new album. John Coltrane's son, Ravi Coltrane, discusses Both Directions at Once: The Lost Album.

titleText: 'Roseanne' Minus Roseanne: ABC Picks Up 'The Conners'
teaserText: ABC was widely praised for giving up a highly rated show on principle when it canceled its Roseanne reboot. It turns out it wasn't quite that simple.

titleText: Animated History: The Evolution Of Parenting
teaserText: A new theory claims that sharing — first of child care and food, but later more complex things — were the original secrets of our species' success.

titleText: Talks Between South Sudan Leaders Find No Appetite For Concessions
teaserText: Hopes for peace are hampered as talks come to an end in Ethiopia. The leaders of South Sudan's warring factions, Salva Kiir and Riek Machar, found little common ground.

titleText: D.C. Sniper Lee Malvo To Get New Sentencing Hearings
teaserText: Tried as a juvenile in the 2002 slayings of 10 people, Lee Boyd Malvo got multiple life sentences without parole. Now, an appeals court has affirmed that several of the sentences must be tossed.

titleText: Keystone Virus Makes First Known Jump From Mosquitoes To Humans
teaserText: A 16-year-old Florida boy is the first person known to have become infected, researchers say. Symptoms in humans include a rash and mild fever.

titleText: PHOTOS: World Cup Brings Sunny Vibes To The Streets Of Senegal
teaserText: Residents of Dakar beat drums, danced and waved flags in the streets to celebrate their triumph over Poland this week. Next up: Japan on Sunday.

titleText: Emails Raise Questions About Interior Secretary Zinke's Link With Oil Executive
teaserText: Congressional Democrats and a public watchdog group are calling for an ethics investigation into the secretary over a land deal between Zinke's family foundation and oil and gas company Halliburton.

titleText: Laws That Criminalize Spread Of Infectious Diseases Can Increase Their Stigma
teaserText: About a dozen states have added hepatitis C to the list of medical conditions for which people can face criminal prosecution if they knowingly engage in activities that could spread the disease.

titleText: EU Tariffs Take Effect, Retaliating For Trump's Taxes On Imported Steel And Aluminum
teaserText: More than $3 billion worth of U.S. goods — from bourbon and peanut butter to Harley-Davidson motorcycles — are now under a 25 percent tariff in Europe.

titleText: 'A Very English Scandal' Stars Who Else But A Very English Hugh Grant
teaserText: Grant plays popular progressive Jeremy Thorpe in the TV miniseries coming soon to Amazon. Thorpe's political career ended in the 1970s after an ex-lover accused him of an affair and a murder plot.

titleText: How Hugh Grant Wants To Make You Rethink Tabloid Culture
Hugh Grant On Smart Romantic Comedies And Standing Up To The Tabloids
A Latino Nonprofit Is Holding Separated Kids. Is That Care Or Complicity Or Both?
teaserText: Southwest Key has, for many years, operated shelters that house unaccompanied migrant children. The family separation policy shined a spotlight on that work -- and raised uncomfortable questions.

titleText: Mother And Son Reunite At Airport; U.S. Had Split Them Because Of Migrant Status
What We Know: Family Separation And 'Zero Tolerance' At The Border
Watch: 6-Year-Old Girl, Alone, Breaks Through Immigration Noise With A Phone Number
'The Catcher Was A Spy': World War II Biopic Barely Singles
teaserText: Despite a fascinating subject and an impressive cast, this tale of MLB catcher Moe Berg's stint as an OSS agent simply presents the facts without generating any insights.

titleText: Elvis Documentary Comes For 'The King' — And Does Not Miss
Dino Vs. The Volcano: 'Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom' Generates Intermittent Heat
